notes: My grandma used to say it, and then my mom

idiom-es: Como el perro de las dos tortas
translation: When someone is so indecisive they end up with nothing
notes: Used a couple of times, but message is still relevant
Direct Translation: Like the dog with two tortas

notes: When my dad says this to me, I know it's going to be a big favor
Usually used when surprised about something
A friendly reminder to take the other person serious
Obviously 10x better than simply saying 'no way'
A classic, it always somehow uplifts me

translation: Depending on context it can mean two things. It can be taken as "ok you got it" or taking note on someones rude behavior
notes: When my mom says this, I need to be careful with my next steps
I remember being obsessed with this phrase when I was seven

translation: trying to do two things at once, but not possible
notes: I get this one a lot, a nice reminder to slow down because I'm not invincible

idiom-es: Andar con el Jesus en la boca
notes: My grandma uses this one a lot, she's always running around doing a lot
Direct Translation: Having the Jesus on the mouth

translation: Stay aware, stay alert, don't be played for a fool
notes: My grandfather gave me this advice when I was like eleven/twelve, it's honestly something I always think about, especially after living on my own
When my mom uses this, I know she knows more than I think she does

translation: Used when you want someone to share
notes: This is used a lot when it comes to food and money

translation: It's over, but in a disappointing way
notes: Whenever this is said, there's no way to fix it

translation: Literally, wherever the wind takes us
notes: I have a lot of good memories starting with this phrase

translation: Another form to say you're playing dumb
notes: This one is very lighthearted, I usually get it when I'm bored and I do random tasks to keep myself busy
This word usually implies a really good snack

idiom-es: Se te va aparecer el diablo por un boquete
translation: Trouble or something bad will find you
notes: I usually get this when I'm being mischievous
Direct Translation: The devil is going to appear to you through a gap/hole

translation: To look around, typically window shopping
notes: This was good to hear when you were bored at home

translation: Some things you have to do on your own
notes: It took me a while to understand what this meant, but after a while it makes sense

translation: A badass, but also depending on context it could mean being an ass
notes: My dad usually says this whenever I achieve something big, it's honestly one of my favorite phrases
It's always a little sad to hear this one
Direct Translation: They took you to the dance

notes: I'm still a little new to this one, but I'm optimistic of the contexts it will be used for
An iconic phrase used by my grandfather
A nice reminder to not be mean

idiom-es: Te va salir mas caro el caldo que las albondigas
translation: When something will cost you more than it should
notes: I usually hear this when people try to take the long way just so they can avoid one small inconvenience, which ends up becoming a big inconvenience in general
Direct Translation: The broth will cost you more than the meatballs
